DT Article
TI BIOSTRATIGRAPHIC AND PALEOZOOGEOGRAPHIC REVIEW OF THE UPPER
   APTIAN-ALBIAN OSTRACODS OF RIACHUELO FORMATION, SERGIPE-ALAGOAS BASIN,
   NORTHEASTERN BRAZIL.
AU Antonietto, Lucas Silveira (antoniettols@gmail.com) 
   Do Carmo, Dermeval Aparecido
   Viviers, Marta Claudia
   Adorno, Rodrigo Rodrigues
SO Revista Brasileira de Paleontologia
VL 18
IS 3
PS 355-368
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A biostratigraphic and paleozoogeographic revision of the upper
   Aptian-Albian ostracods of Riachuelo Formation, in the Sergipe-Alagoas
   Basin, Brazil, was conducted. The studied material comprised 336 samples
   from several outcrops, along with well cores drilled by Petroleo
   Brasileiro S.A. (PETROBRAS). After taxonomic analysis, including the
   description of Reticulocosta edrianae n. sp., a new biozonation scheme
   was obtained for the Albian interval of that formation, and the
   paleozoogeographic affinities of the Brazil-Central West Africa province
   were reviewed through comparison with results published in the current
   literature. Several changes were made to previously established ostracod
   zones. A new code for the Aracajuia benderi Zone (OSE-1), MSA-0, was
   created, with impact in all of its subzones. The names of the
   Pattersoncypris ex. gr. angulata (OSE-1.1), 'Patellacythere' sp. GA E 27
   (OSE-1.3) and Veenia guianensis (OSE-1.4) subzones were changed to
   Harbinia sinuata? (MSA-0.1), Praebythoceratina amsittenensis (MSA-0.3)
   and Reticulocosta edrianae (MSA-0.4), respectively. The Sergipella
   viviersae Subzone (OSE-1.2) had its code changed for MSA-0.2; also, a
   stratotype was stablished for it, and the lower limit of the subzone was
   changed, from lower Albian in previous works to upper Aptian. The
   Metacytheropteon aff. Metacytheropteron sp. GA C 24 Subzone (OSE-1.5)
   was renamed MSA-0.5. The uppermost Albian Aracajuia antiqua Latest
   Occurrence Interval Zone (MSA-1) is herein proposed, following the
   reclassification Aracajuia benderi specimens of the Aracajuia benderi
   Subzone (OSE-1.6) to Aracajuia antiqua. Paleozoogeographic analyses
   showed some faunal interchange with Tethyan provinces, beginning in the
   latest Aptian, at both specific and generic levels. Limited northward
   marine influxes across the Walvis ridge were also observed during the
   Albian, while larger scale southward migrations occurred in the early
   Cenomanian. The presence of Brachycytherinae species in the
   Brazil-Central West Africa province as early as the Aptian indicates a
   new zoogeographic origin for this subfamily, while explaining the
   occurrence of the group in both the Austral realm and part of the
   Tethyan realm during the Albian.
C1 Antonietto, Lucas Silveira; Univ Brasilia, Inst Geociencias, Campus
   Darcy Ribeiro, Brasilia, DF, BR-70919970 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM antoniettols@gmail.com
RI Antonietto, Lucas S/T-4006-2017; Carmo, Dermeval Aparecido
   Do/AAL-9767-2020
OI Antonietto, Lucas S/0000-0002-6571-0869; Carmo, Dermeval Aparecido
   Do/0000-0002-1613-7242
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1519-7530
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Ecology; Zoogeography; Land zones;
   Afrotropical region; Neotropical region; South America; Geological time
   periods; Mesozoic
DE Brachycytherinae [Africa / West Africa, central / distribution] [Brazil
   /  / ] [Cretaceous / Aptian / ]. 
   Ostracoda [Fossil assemblages /  / review] [Zoogeography /
   Palaeozoogeography / ] [Brazil / Sergipe-Alagoas Basin / stratigraphical
   distribution] [Cretaceous / Upper Aptian to Albian / ]. 
   Reticulocosta edrianae [Brazil /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Ostracoda
OR Ostracoda (Crustacea): [Fossil]. 
   Brachycytherinae (Ostracoda): [Fossil]. 
   Reticulocosta edrianae (Ostracoda): [Sp nov, Brazil, Cretaceous, P. 360;
   Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15205029938
OA Bronze
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15205029943
DT Article
TI SYSTEMATIC UPDATE AND PHYLOGENY OF THE PROTEROTHERIIDAE (MAMMALIA,
   LITOPTERNA) FROM THE 'MESOPOTAMIENSE' (LATE MIOCENE) OF ENTRE RIOS
   PROVINCE, ARGENTINA.
FT ACTUALIZACION SISTEMATICA Y FILOGENIA DE LOS PROTEROTHERIIDAE (MAMMALIA,
   LITOPTERNA) DEL 'MESOPOTAMIENSE' (MIOCENO TARDIO) DE ENTRE RIOS,
   ARGENTINA.
AU Ines Schmidt, Gabriela (gschmidt@cicyttp.org.ar) 
SO Revista Brasileira de Paleontologia
VL 18
IS 3
PS 521-546
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB A systematic update of the species of Proterotheriidae (Litoptema) from
   the "Mesopotamiense" of Entre Rios Province (Argentina) is performed,
   and their phylogenetic relationships with other members of the family
   are tested. Brachytherium cuspidatum Ameghino is validated (considered
   nomen dubium hitherto) and a sexual dimorphism is proposed for this
   species. This idea is based on metric, but not morphological,
   differences among the specimens included in it, which is supported by a
   discriminant analysis. Neobrachytherium ameghinoi Soria and
   Proterotherium cervioides Ameghino are also valid, and Epitherium?
   eversus (Ameghino) is assigned to the genus Diadiaphorus. Detailed
   descriptions of the specimens are presented for each taxon, and their
   diagnosis are revised.
C1 Ines Schmidt, Gabriela; Ctr Invest Cient & Transferencia Tecnol Prod
   CICY, Lab Paleontol Vertebrados, Mat & Espana E3105BWA, Diamante, Entre
   Rios, Argentina, Argentina.
EM gschmidt@cicyttp.org.ar
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology; Paleontology
SN 1519-7530
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Diagnosis; Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Evolution; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America;
   Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene
DE Proterotheriidae [Phylogeny /  / Systematics] [Argentina / Entre Rios /
   ] [Miocene / Late Miocene / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Litopterna
OR Brachytherium cuspidatum - Ameghino 1883 (Litopterna): [Emended
   diagnosis, P. 526; Status, P. 528]. 
   Diadiaphorus - Ameghino 1887 (Litopterna): [Emended diagnosis, P. 533]. 
   Diadiaphorus eversus - (Ameghino 1891) (Litopterna): [Emended diagnosis,
   P. 534; Comb nov, Transferred from Epitherium, p. 534]. 
   Epitherium? eversus - (Ameghino 1891) (Litopterna): [Referred to,
   Diadiaphorus, p. 534]. 
   Neobrachytherium - Soria 2001 (Litopterna): [Emended diagnosis, P. 530].
   
   Neobrachytherium ameghinoi - Soria 2001 (Litopterna): [Emended
   diagnosis, P. 530; Status, P. 531]. 
   Proterotheriidae (Litopterna): [Fossil]. 
   Proterotherium cervioides - Ameghino 1883 (Litopterna): [Emended
   diagnosis, P. 532; Status, P. 532].

DT Article
TI New Species and Subspecies of african Cerambycidae (Coleoptera,
   Cerambycidae).
FT Neue Spezies und Subspezies afrikanischer Cerambyciden (Coleoptera,
   Cerambycidae).
AU Adlbauer, Karl
SO Cahiers Magellanes-NS
VL 19
PS 1-12
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA German
U1 0
U2 1
AB The following Cerambycidae are described as new: Holorusius ethiopicus
   sp. n. (Smodicini, Ethiopia); Paroeme elongata sp. n. (Oemini, Nigeria,
   Cameroon); Corioeme ugandensis sp. n. (Gemini, Uganda); Pelossus becki
   (Pelossini, Ethiopia); Pelossus similis sp. n. (Pelossini, Zamiba,
   Tanzania); Cordylomera schmidi sp. n. (Phoracanthini, Cameroon);
   Sassandrioides puchneri sp. n. (Callidiopini, Cameroon); Puchneriana
   camerunensis gen. n., sp. n. (Obriini, Cameroon); Strandiata lizleri sp.
   n. (Lamiini, Ethiopia) and Dichostates tabularis kenyensis ssp. n.
   (Ceroplesini, Subtribus CrossOtina, Kenya).

PT J
AN ZOOR15204022428
DT Article
TI Synonymies, diagnoses and bionomics of some african Lamiinae, 22nd note,
   2nd part (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae, Lamiinae).
FT Synonymies, diagnoses et bionomie de quelques Lamiaires africains, 22e
   note, 2e partie (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae, Lamiinae).
AU Teocchi, Pierre (jsudre@hotmail.com) 
   Sudre, Jerome
   Jiroux, Eric
SO Cahiers Magellanes-NS
VL 19
PS 15-40
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB Informations are given on several species of African Lamiinae. One new
   genus, one new subgenus and three new species are described:
   Freocoreopsis gen. nov., Ebogodyenmonus sub gen. nov., Oxylamia hastiri
   sp. nov., Freocoreopsis juheli sp. nov., Ebogodyenmonus rousseti sp.
   nov. Seven taxa are synonymized : Pterolophia ivorensis Breuning, 1967
   and P. szewezycki Lepesme & Breuning, 1955 = Pterolophia lepida
   Breuning, 1938; Lagrida similis Breuning, 1937 = L. aenea Hintz, 1919;
   Exocentrus fuscomarmoratus Breuning, 1970 and E. lateriplagiatus Teocchi
   et al., 2014 = E. sudanicus Aurivillius, 1927; Obereopsis holoflava
   Breuning, 1955 and Obereopsis endroedii Breuning, 1973 = Obereopsis
   villiersi Lepesme & Breuning, 1953. The genus Lagrida and Mimolagrida
   are respectively transfered from Crossotini tribe and Tragocephalini
   tribe to Theocridini tribe.
C1 Teocchi, Pierre; 210 Chemin Bois Barthelasse, Avignon, F-84000, France,
   France.

DT Article
TI Ten new Longhorn Beetles from Southeast Asia and Remarks to the Genus
   Microdymasius Pic, 1946 (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae).
FT Zehn neue Bockkafer aus Sudostasien und Bemerkungen zur Gattung
   Microdymasius Pic, 1946 (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae).
AU Holzschuh, Carolus
SO Cahiers Magellanes-NS
VL 19
PS 41-53
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Ten New Longhorn beetles from Southeast Asia and remarks to the Genus
   Microdymasius Pic, 1946 (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae). Described and
   illustrated are Dymasius uncatus sp. nov., Oligoenoplus polymites sp.
   nov., and Oligoenoplus zonifer sp. nov. from Borneo; Encyclops
   obscurellus sp. nov., Dymasius querceus sp.nov. and Novorondonia
   antennata sp. nov. from China; Noemia luctuosa sp. nov., Dymasius
   lineolatus sp. nov., and Novorondonia arcuata sp. nov. from Laos and
   Oligoenoplus viduatus from India. Sebasmia nigra Gahan, 1906 is
   transferred to Microdymasius Pic, 1946 and Microdymasius honestus
   Holzschuh, 1999 is considered as a synonym of M. niger (Gahan, 1906).
C1 Holzschuh, Carolus; Spitzeckweg 11, Villach, A-9500, Austria, Austria.

TI New neotropical Cerambycidae (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae, Cerambycinae).
FT Nouveaux Cerambycinae neotropicaux (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae,
   Cerambycinae).
AU Audureau, Alain (golofa@golofa.fr) 
SO Cahiers Magellanes-NS
VL 19
PS 60-66
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB One new genus and two new species of Hexoplonini are described :
   Paratetroplon gen. nov., Paratetroplon michelroberti sp. nov. and
   Gnomidolon galileoae sp. nov. from Peru. Four new species of Ibidionini
   are also described : Engyum martinsi sp. nov. from Peru, Microibidion
   kawensis sp. nov. from French Guiana, Stenoidion nicaraguaensis sp. nov.
   and Compsibidion marqueti sp. nov. from Nicaragua.

AN ZOOR15204022432
DT Article
TI [Catoeme raminahisoae n. sp., the first representative of the genus
   Catoeme Aurivillius from Madagascar (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae).]
FT Catoeme raminahisoae n. sp., premier representant du genre Catoeme
   Aurivillius a Madagascar (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae).
AU Bonneau, Patrick (alastor.pb@sfr.fr) 
   Vitali, Francesco
SO Cahiers Magellanes-NS
VL 19
PS 67-73
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Catoeme Aurivillius, 1908, Catoeme
   raminahisoae n. sp., from Madagascar is described. This new species
   differs from all its congeners in its peculiar zigzag pattern. The genus
   Catoeme Aurivillius, 1908 is considered older subjective synonym of
   Thapsyrus Villiers, 1972 n. syn. and the following combinations are
   proposed: Catoeme arnoldi Corinta Ferreira, 1955 rest. comb., Catoeme
   martellii (Villiers, 1972) n. comb. and Catoeme quentini (Villiers,
   1972) n. comb. Catoeme brincki Tippmann, 1959 is recorded from Zambia
   for the first time. Finally, a key to the genus Catoeme is added.
C1 Bonneau, Patrick; 3 Lot Les Vignes, La Bouilladisse, F-13720, France,
   France.
EM alastor.pb@sfr.fr
SC Zoology
SN 1624-1940
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Taxonomic position; Key; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Catoeme brincki [Zambia /  / New record]. 
   Catoeme raminahisoae [Madagascar /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates

   Cerambycidae
OR Catoeme - Aurivillius 1908 (Cerambycidae): [Syn nov, Thapsyrus Villiers
   in Breuning & Villiers 1972, p. 70; Key to species, P. 72]. 
   Catoeme arnoldi - Corinta-Ferreira 1955 (Cerambycidae): [Combination
   revalidated, Transferred back from Thapsyrus, p. 70]. 
   Catoeme brincki (Cerambycidae): [New record]. 
   Catoeme martellii - (Villiers in Breuning & Villiers 1972)
   (Cerambycidae): [Comb nov, Transferred from Thapsyrus, p. 70]. 
   Catoeme quentini - (Villiers in Breuning & Villiers 1972)
   (Cerambycidae): [Comb nov, Transferred from Thapsyrus, p. 71]. 
   Catoeme raminahisoae (Cerambycidae): [Sp nov, Madagascar, P. 68]. 
   Thapsyrus arnoldi - (Corinta-Ferreira 1955) (Cerambycidae): [Referred
   to, Catoeme, p. 70]. 
   Thapsyrus martellii - Villiers in Breuning & Villiers 1972
   (Cerambycidae): [Referred to, Catoeme, p. 70]. 
   Thapsyrus quentini - Villiers in Breuning & Villiers 1972
   (Cerambycidae): [Referred to, Catoeme, p. 71].

AB The genus Eulitoclonius Schmidt is synonymized with the genus Hospes

   litomecoides (Schmidt). The following new taxons are described: Hospes
   bouyeri n. sp., Hospes dargei n. sp., Hospes kaboboensis n. sp., Hospes
   maniemaensis n. sp., Hospes erwanni n. sp., Hospes nitidicollis drumonti

DT Article
TI Eighteenth contribution to the study of Callichromatini africains:
   taxonomic notes and description of three species and two new sub species
   (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae, Cerambycinae, Callichromatini).
FT Dix-neuvieme contribution a l'etude des Callichromatini africains :
   notes taxonomiques et description de trois especes et deux sousespeces
   nouvelles (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae, Cerambycinae, Callichromatini).
AU Juhel, Pierre
SO Cahiers Magellanes-NS
VL 19
PS 84-98
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB Callichroma cylindricum White is transferred in the genus Conamblys, n.
   comb., Hoplomeces Aurivillius is revalidated and the species Hoplomeces
   laevicollis Aurivillius and Hoplomeces asper Aurivillius are restored in
   this genus, rest. stat. The sub-genus Cloniophorus (Cycloclonius)
   Schmidt is raised to the rank of genus Cycloclonius Schmidt, n. stat.
   Callichroma parallelipenne Quedenfeldt is transferred in the genus
   Psilomastix Schmidt, n. comb. The following new taxons are described:
   Colobizus aurivillii n. sp., Litomeces (Eulitopus) glabricollis
   ituriensis n. ssp., Cycloclonius tristani n. sp., Synaptola bouyeri n.
   sp., Euporus itimbirensis bouyeri n. ssp.

PT J
AN ZOOR15204022266
DT Article
TI Factor driving heterotrophic dinoflagellate in relation to environment
   conditions in Kerkennah Islands (eastern coast of Tunisa).
AU Ben Brahim, Mounir (benbrahim.mounir@gmail.com) 
   Feki, Morsi
   Feki-Sahnoun, Wafa
   Mahfoudi, Mabrouka
   Hamza, Asma
SO Journal of Coastal Life Medicine
VL 3
IS 9
PS 686-690
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Objective: To study the seasonal variability of heterotrophic
   dinoflagellate in the station of Cercina (southern coast of Tunisia).
   Methods: Sampling was done in 2007 in Cercina station located in the
   western coast of Kerkennah (34[degree]41'27'' N; 11[degree]07'45''E)
   (Southern Tunisia). Three replicates of water samples were taken during
   10 days of each month. Environmental variables and nutrients were
   measured in situ. Results: A significant seasonal difference was
   observed for temperature and water salinity. The highest values were
   observed in spring and summer. No significant seasonal difference was,
   however, detected for nitrite, nitrate, ammonia, silica and phosphate.
   Sixty-five species of dinoflagellate were identified in the station of
   Cercina. Abundance of dinoflagellates fluctuated between seasons with
   values showing a significant seasonal and monthly difference. The
   highest mean abundance was recorded in spring in April, while the lowest
   abundance was detected in December in winter. Protoperidinium granii was
   the main species contributing to the dissimilarity between spring and
   winter with 13.98% followed by Peridinium sp. with 12.5% of
   dissimilarity and by Polykrikos sp. with 10.58%. Conclusions:
   Heterotrophic dinoflagellates proliferate in spring and summer. This
   increase was justified by the nutrient availability. Protoperidinium
   granii and Polykrikos kofoidii were the main heterotrophic
   dinoflagellate making difference between seasons and their densities
   were positively correlated with both temperature and salinity.
C1 Ben Brahim, Mounir; Ctr Sfax, Natl Inst Sci & Technol Sea, BP 1035,
   Sfax, 3018, Tunisia, Tunisia.
EM benbrahim.mounir@gmail.com
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 2309-5288; 2309-6152
BD Ecology; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean; North Atlantic
DE Dinoflagellata [Biomass /  / heterotrophic taxa] [Population dynamics /
   Seasonal abundance / ] [Mediterranean Sea / Tunisia, Kerkennah Islands,
   Cercina / ]. 
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Sarcomastigophora, Mastigophora, Phytomastigophorea,
   Dinoflagellida
OR Dinoflagellata (Dinoflagellida). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15204022266
OA DOAJ Gold
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15204022729
PM 26527840
DT Article
TI A New Species of Pristionchus (Rhabditida: Diplogastridae) and Its
   Bacterial Symbiont from Yixing, China.
AU Li, Pengpeng (keyunzhang@njau.edu.cn) 
   Dai, Chensheng
   Bao, Haoran
   Chen, Long
   Gao, Di
   Wang, Guoxiang
   Wang, Jin
   Wang, Hui
   Yedid, Gabriel
   Zhang, Keyun
SO Journal of Nematology
VL 47
IS 3
PS 190-197
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB A new nernatode species, Pristionchus entamophilus n. sp., was collected
   during a soil sample surs-ey in Yixing of Jiangsu province, eastern
   China. P entomophilus n. sp is distinguished by its unique
   characteristics. Dills new species is mainly hermaphroditic, with males
   seldom found. The new nematode has a similar body length but has much
   narrower body width compared with P pactficus. Its body is covered with
   longitudinal ridges: 12 ridges on head, 13 or 14 ridges in the middle,
   11 and 7 ridges in front and rear of the anus, respectively. The
   eurystomatous form mouth includes a triangular dorsal tooth, a large
   claw like right subventral tooth, and a row of five ventral denticles
   placed opposite the dorsal tooth. Only eight pairs of genital papillae
   and a pair of phasmids are present in the tail of the male as the sixth
   pair of papillae having seemingly been degenerated and lost. Molecular
   phylogenetic trees based on 135 rDNA confirmed that the new species
   belongs to the genus Pristionchus and is most closely related to P
   pacificus. Moreover-, the new species was found to be occasionally
   associated with the entomopathogenic bacterial strain 09F1,YBI of
   Serratia nematodophila and be able to stably transfer the bacterial
   strain for sever 7a1 generations.
C1 Li, Pengpeng; Nanjing Agr Univ, Dept Zool, Nanjing, Jiangsu, 210095,
   China, China.
EM keyunzhang@njau.edu.cn
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 0022-300X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Associations; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Pristionchus [Associations / Serratia (bacterium) / New record;
   symbiosis] [Jiangsu / Yixing / Bacterial associates]. 
   Pristionchus entomophilus [Jiangsu /  / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Nematoda
OR Pristionchus (Nematoda): [New record]. 
   Pristionchus entomophilus (Nematoda): [Sp nov, Jiangsu, Host unknown, p.
   191].

PT J
AN ZOOR15203016789
DT Article
TI THE STUDY ON THE MAIKHANELLIDS IN THE MEISHUCUN STAGE FROM XIXIANG
   SOUTHERN SHAANXI PROVINCE, NW CHINA.
AU Shao, Tiequan (stotto@163.com) 
   Wang, Qi
   Liu, Yunhuan
   Tang, Hanhua
   Li, Yuan
   Zheng, Panlin
   Zhu, Chengyu
   Liu, Futian
   Qin, Juan
   He, Huahua
   Liu, Siyu
SO Acta Micropalaeontologica Sinica
VL 32
IS 3
PS 329-338
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 1
AB Maikhanellids represent a group of the oldest monoplacophorans and they
   are important fossils in the Kuanchuanpu Member, Meishucun Stage.
   According to the individual shell shape and ornamentation types of 64
   maikhanellids fossils which were collected from Xixiang Biota, Xixiang
   County, Shaanxi Province, NW China, we confirmed that the family
   Maikhanellidae consists of six genera. A new species Mediata
   xixiangensis sp. nov. is described in this paper. We also took EDAX
   analysis in different parts of those fossils and morphological
   measurements. The ingredients of Maikhanellids' shell are calcium
   phosphate with a small amount of fluorine and aluminum elements.
   Maikhanellids are small and no more than 1 mm, generally 300-700 [mu]m
   long, 250-550 [mu]m wide, and 200-300 [mu]m thick. This study is of
   significance for the research of the Monoplacophora.
C1 Shao, Tiequan; Changan Univ, Fac Earth Sci & Resources, Xian, 710054,
   China, China.
EM stotto@163.com
SC Zoology
SN 1000-0674
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia; China; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic

   Meishucunian / ]. 
   Mediata xixiangensis [Shaanxi /  / new species] [Cambrian /  / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs

   338; Fossil].

DT Article
TI A Pleistocene mammal assemblage containing Ailuropoda and Pongo from
   Tham Prakai Phet cave, Chaiyaphum Province, Thailand.
AU Filoux, Arnaud (filoux_arnaud@yahoo.fr) 
   Wattanapituksakul, Athiwat
   Lespes, Carole
   Thongcharoenchaikit, Cholawit
SO Geobios (Villeurbanne)
VL 48
IS 5
PS 341-349
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 2
U2 11
AB Mammal remains have been collected during surveys between December, 2011
   and April, 2013, in a cave in the Chaiyaphum Province, Northeastern
   Thailand, by a team from Mahasarakham University and the Natural History
   Museum of the National Science Museum of Thailand. The Tham Prakai Phet
   (the cave of glittering diamonds) is a long karstic cavity formed in a
   Permian dolomitic limestone and already known to contain Pleistocene
   mammals. In the 1990s, some fossil teeth provided by a monk were
   identified as Crocuta crocuta ultima, Rhinoceros sondaicus, Sus cf.
   barbatus, Muntiacus muntjak, Axis porcinus, Cervidae indet., Bos
   sauveli, and Naemorhedus sumatraensis. The collection studied in this
   work contains newly discovered taxa including: Pongo sp., Macaca sp.,
   Ailuropoda melanoleuca, Panthera cf. pardus, Ursus thibetanus, Bos
   javanicus, Bos sp., Bubalus sp., Naemorhedus sp., Sus scrofa, Rusa
   unicolor, and Hystrix cf. indica. The new data reveal a considerably
   more diverse Pleistocene faunal assemblage than previously documented.
   The age of the fauna is Pleistocene, probably not older than the late
   Middle Pleistocene. Gnaw marks on some of the remains suggest that the
   assemblage was possibly at least partly accumulated by rodents. (C) 2015
   Elsevier Masson SAS. All rights reserved.
C1 Filoux, Arnaud; Mahasarakham Univ, Palaeontol Res & Educ Ctr,
   Mahasarakham, 44150, Thailand, Thailand.
EM filoux_arnaud@yahoo.fr
SC Zoology; Paleontology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0016-6995
BD Ecology; Fossilization; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia;
   Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Quaternary
DE Mammalia [Fossil assemblages /  / Description] [Taphonomy /  / ]
   [Thailand / Chaiyaphum Province, Tham Prakai Phet cave / ] [Pleistocene
   /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata
OR Mammalia (Vertebrata): [Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15203016035
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15203016036
DT Article
TI First reported Late Ordovician trilobites from the High Zagros Ranges,
   Iran: A biogeographic link between Gondwanan Chinese and Mediterranean
   faunas.
AU Pour, Mansoureh Ghobadi
   Ghavidel-Syooki, Mohammad
   Javier Alvaro, J. (jj.alvaro@csic.es) 
   Popov, Leonid E.
   Ehsani, Mohammad H.
SO Geobios (Villeurbanne)
VL 48
IS 5
PS 351-369
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB The study of the Upper Ordovician in the Faraghan Mountains,
   southeastern Iran, reveals for the first time the presence of a
   low-diversity trilobite fauna in the middle member of the Seyahou
   Formation. Five genera and nine species have been identified, including
   Dalmanitina (Dalmanitina) dargazensis nov. sp. Four species are
   described under open nomenclature and the affiliation of four taxa was
   possible only to the generic level. Overall, this trilobite assemblage
   shows strong affinities with high-to-mid latitude, peri-Gondwanan
   faunas, and displays close similarities with taxa from the Mediterranean
   margin of Gondwana (mainly Sardinia and Bohemia/Perunica) and, to a
   lesser extent, with the Turkish Taurides. The age of the Iranian
   trilobite fauna is well constrained, due to its co-occurrence with
   chitinozoans, which reveal a biostratigraphic interval ranging from the
   upper part of the Acanthochitina barbata to the Armoricochitina nigerica
   zones, mid-to-late Katian in age. (C) 2015 Elsevier Masson SAS. All
   rights reserved.

   Madrid, 28040, Spain, Spain.

PT J
AN ZOOR15203016037
DT Article
TI Intraspecific variation and taphonomy of a new erymid lobster
   (Crustacea: Decapoda) from the Middle Jurassic of Belmont (Beaujolais,
   France).
AU Hyzny, Matus (hyzny.matus@gmail.com) 
   Schloegl, Jan
   Charbonnier, Sylvain
   Schweigert, Guenter
   Rulleau, Louis
   Gouttenoire, Michel
SO Geobios (Villeurbanne)
VL 48
IS 5
PS 371-384
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 1
U2 4
AB Erymid lobsters are relatively common in Jurassic rocks, but usually
   only occur as isolated carapaces or chelae. As a consequence,
   intraspecific variation, possible sexual dimorphism and heterochely
   remain poorly known in this group. New material from the Middle Jurassic
   (Aalenian) of Belmont. France, consists of specimens belonging to
   approximately 20 individuals with well-preserved carapaces retaining
   both chelipeds. A re-evaluation of selected taxa of the Erymidae is
   presented, in which Etyma, Palaeastacus and Erymastacus are considered
   valid genera. However, Stenodactylina is interpreted to be a junior
   subjective synonym of Erymastacus. Intraspecific variation in the length
   and curvature of fingers in Etymastacus lagardettei nov. sp., is
   highlighted, raising doubts as to the relevance of isolated chelae as
   the basis for new species designation. Interestingly, carapaces from
   Belmont often exhibit damaged posterior parts, which are here
   tentatively interpreted as cephalopod scavenging marks. (C) 2015
   Elsevier Masson SAS. All rights reserved.
C1 Hyzny, Matus; Nat Hist Museum Vienna, Geol Palaentol Dept, Burgring 7,
   Vienna, A-1010, Austria, Austria.
EM hyzny.matus@gmail.com

AN ZOOR15203016038
DT Article
TI Upper Albian chelonioid turtles from Poland.
AU Kapuscinska, Agnieszka
   Machalski, Marcin (mach@twarda.pan.pl) 
SO Geobios (Villeurbanne)
VL 48
IS 5
PS 385-395
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Remains of chelonioid turtles assigned to Protostegidae are recorded
   from the upper Albian (Lower Cretaceous) sands at Annopol, Poland. These
   are the first remains of Cretaceous marine turtles from Poland. A
   semi-articulated partial carapace with an associated postorbital bone is
   referred to as Protostegidae gen. et sp. indet. A. Scute sulci are
   visible on each preserved costal and neural plate of this specimen,
   which suggests hypertrophy and multiplication of vertebral scutes, a
   unique feature among chelonioids. An isolated humerus from the same
   level as the carapace is referred to as Protostegidae gen. et sp. indet.
   B. The massive lateral process of this humerus extends significantly
   onto the ventral surface of the bone, like in some humeri of primitive
   protostegids from the European Cretaceous, including the Albian
   "Lytoloma cantabrigiense" from England and Turonian "Rhinochelys (7) cf.
   carusiana" from Germany. (C) 2015 Elsevier Masson SAS. All rights
   reserved.
C1 Machalski, Marcin; Polish Acad Sci, Inst Paleobiol, Ul Twarda 51-55,
   Warsaw, PL-00818, Poland, Poland.
EM mach@twarda.pan.pl
RI Machalski, Marcin/AAX-1074-2020
OI Machalski, Marcin/0000-0002-1121-4093; Kapuscinska,
   Agnieszka/0000-0002-8050-2582
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0016-6995
BD Ecology; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological
   time periods; Mesozoic
DE Protostegidae [Fossil assemblages /  / New record; systematics] [Poland
   / Annopol / ] [Cretaceous / Upper Albian / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates

   Cryptodira

AN ZOOR15203018131
DT Article
TI Freshwater sponges from the Pampa Biome, Brazil, with description of a
   new species of Oncosclera.
AU Tavares-Frigo, Maria da Conceicao (maria-tavares@fzb.rs.gov.br) 
   Volkmer-Ribeiro, Cecilia
   Zanini de Oliveira, Ana Elenice
   Machado, Vanessa de Souza
SO Neotropical Biology and Conservation
VL 10
IS 3
PS 110-122
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Environmental Protection Area of Ibirapuita embodies the upper
   portion of the Ibirapuita River, which drains a representative part of
   the Pampa Biome in Brazil. A survey for the sponge fauna in this region
   was needed in view of the few registers available and none for this
   protected area. Following that purpose, three expeditions were carried
   on in 2011, four in 2012 and one in 2013, along four stations in the
   Ibirabuita River and one in Sarandizinho its contributing brook.
   Sampling was done crossing the river/brook rocky bottoms by foot and
   sampling the sponges manually. The study indicated the occurrence of a
   new species of the genus Oncosclera Volkmer-Ribeiro, O. rosariae n. sp.,
   besides O. navicella and O. schubarti (Potamolepidae), and Heteromeyenia
   insignis, Corvoheteromeyenia australis and Corvospongilla seckti
   (Spongillidae). The surveyed assemblage is representative of stony
   shallow lotic environments subjected to remarkable high levels and low
   temperatures of the waters in the winter. The results disclosed the
   existence of five unique sponge assemblages of lotic environments for
   the whole Pampa Biome. A key to the sponge species occurring at the
   Environmental Protection Area of Ibirapuita is presented.
C1 Tavares-Frigo, Maria da Conceicao; Fundacao Zoobot Rio Grande Sul, Museu
   Ciencias Nat, Caixa Postal 1188, Porto Alegre, RS, BR-90001970 BC,
   Brazil, Brazil.
EM maria-tavares@fzb.rs.gov.br
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Marine &Freshwater Biology
SN 1809-9939
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Ecology; Habitat;
   Freshwater habitat; Lotic water; Abiotic factors; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; South America
DE Oncosclera rosariae [Brazil /  / New species]. 
   Porifera [Brazil / Rio Grande do Sul, Ibirapuita / Key to species]. 
   Spongillidae [Community structure /  / systematics] [River /  /
   distribution] [Abiotic factors / Physical & chemical parameters / ]
   [Brazil / Rio Grande do Sul, Ibirapuita / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Sponges
ST Animalia, Porifera, Demospongiae
OR Porifera (Animalia): [Key to species, Brazil, Rio Grande do Sul,
   Ibirapuita, P. 118]. 
   Oncosclera rosariae (Demospongiae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 116]. 
   Spongillidae - Gray 1867 (Demospongiae).

DT Article
TI Mites associated with two species of the genus Odontotaenius
   (Coleoptera: Passalidae) in Mexico.
FT Acaros asociados a dos especies de Odontotaenius (Coleoptera:
   Passalidae) en Mexico.
AU Liliana Barrios-Tones, Pilar (plilianabtorres777@hotmail.com) 
   Villegas-Guzman, Gabriel A.
SO Revista de Biologia Tropical
VL 63
IS 3
PS 659-671
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 5
AB Mites can establish association with different arthropods as
   coleopterans families Scarabaeidae and Passalidae. Passalids are
   distributed in tropical and templates zones, and until now, more than
   200 species of mites have been associated to them. One of the
   relationships between passalids and mites is the phoresy where one small
   animal (the phoretic) seeks out and attaches to another animal (the
   host) for transportation. Herein, we studied the mites associated to O.
   zodiacus and O. striatopunctatus; for this, 80 Odontotaenius with mites
   were reviewed; passalids were collected in and under decaying logs from
   six states of Mexico, and were individually kept in vials with 80%
   ethanol. The specimens were carried to the laboratory and mites removed
   with fine-pointed forceps under stereo microscope. The mites were stored
   with 80 % alcohol until some were cleared with lacto-phenol and mounted
   in Hoyer's solution. We found 1 945 mites belonging to 13 families
   (Acaridae, Ascidae, Diarthrophallidae, Digamasellidae, Diplogyniidae,
   Euzerconidae, Heterocheylidae, Histiostomatidae, Klinckowstroemiidae,
   Laelapidae, Megisthanidae, Trematuridae, and Uropodidae) and 42 species,
   being the most abundant species Anoetus sp. For O. striatopunctatus (16
   specimens) we found 562 mites (95 [female][female], 34 [male], 197
   hypopus, 234 deutonymph, 2 tritonymph) of 11 families and 22 species;
   the most abundant were Uropodidae (42 %) and Histiostomatidae (26 %).
   While for 0. zodiacus (64 specimens) were found 1 383 mites (300 9, 204
   66, 608 hypopus, 139 deutonymphs, 133 tritonymphs) of 10 families and 30
   species; the most abundant were: Diartrophallidae, Acaridae, and
   Histiostomatidae (23 % for the two first and 21 % for third). The high
   abundance and richness was in O. zodiacus, likewise Margalef (S') and
   Shanon-Winner (H') indexes were higher in this species (O. zodiacus S' =
   4.05, H' = 2.2; 0 striatopienctatus S' = 3.34, H' = 1.94), while Equity
   (EH) was similar to both hosts (O. zodiacus EH = 0.64; 0.
   striatopunctatus EH = 0.63). The mites were found principally in the
   protected zone of the passalid's body, as under elytron, membranous
   wings, and in the clefts of the ventral region of the passalid, and, in
   minor proportion, on the head and coxal regions. From our findings, 12
   species were new records for the Mexican passalids: Abrotarsala
   cuneiformis, A. obesa, A. pyriformis, Brachytremella sp.,
   Diarthrophallus cartwrighti, D. crinatus, Lombardiniella sp.,
   Trichodiplogynium carlosi, T sahlbergi, T hirsutum and Thichodiplogynium
   sp., and additional studies may help describe and understand these
   mites-passalids associations.
C1 Liliana Barrios-Tones, Pilar; Escuela Nacl Ciencias Biol, IPN, Esquina
   Con Plan de Ayala S-N, Mexico City, DF, 11340, Mexico, Mexico.
EM plilianabtorres777@hotmail.com
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 0034-7744
BD Associations; Commensalism; Land zones; Nearctic region; North America
DE Acari [Phoresy / Odontotaenius striatopunctatus (Coleoptera) / Records
   including new records] [ / Odontotaenius zodiacus (Coleoptera) / ]
   [Mexico /  / Coleopteran phoretic associates]. 
   Odontotaenius striatopunctatus; Odontotaenius zodiacus [Phoresy / Acari
   (Arachnida) / Records including new records] [Mexico /  / Arachnid
   phoretic associates]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Beetles; Chelicerates; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga,
   Scarabaeoidea, Passalidae
OR Acari (Arachnida): [New record]. 
   Odontotaenius striatopunctatus (Passalidae): [New record]. 
   Odontotaenius zodiacus (Passalidae): [New record]. 
DI 10.15517/rbt.v63i3.15745

AN ZOOR15202010020
DT Article
TI Three new species of the genus Oedaleus Fieber, 1853 (Orthoptera,
   Acridoidea, Oedipodidae, Oedipodinae) from Taiwan, with a key to the
   known species of the genus in China.
AU Yin Xiang-Chu (yxch@hbu.edu.cn) 
   Ye Bao-Hua
   Dang Yan
SO Acta Entomologica Sinica
VL 58
IS 9
PS 1012-1018
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three new species of the genus Oedaleus Fieber, 1853 from Taiwan, China
   are described in this paper. Oedaleus xiai sp. nov. differs from all
   known species of the genus by the tegmina shorter, just reaching the end
   of hind femur. Oedaleus kaohsiungensis sp. nov. is similar to Oe.
   formosana (Shiraki, 1910), but differs from the latter by the hind femur
   with black band on inner side and hind tibia yellowish brown, not red.
   Oedaleus nantouensis sp. nov. is similar to Oe. formosana (Shiraki,
   1910), but differs from the latter by eye larger, vertical diameter
   almost equal to subocular furrow and interspace of mesosternum wider,
   minimum width 1.8 times length. Oedaleus nantouensis sp. nov. is also
   allied to Oedaleus kaohsiungensis sp. nov., but differs from the latter
   by hind femur red on lower side and hind tibia red. A key to all 13
   known species of the genus from China is provided. Type specimens are
   deposited in the National Museum of Natural Science, Taichung, Taiwan,
   China.
C1 Yin Xiang-Chu; Hebei Univ, Coll Life Sci, Baoding, Hebei, 071002, China,
   China.
EM yxch@hbu.edu.cn
SC Zoology
SN 0454-6296

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Oedaleus [China /  / Key to species]. 
   Oedaleus kaohsiungensis; Oedaleus nantouensis; Oedaleus xiai [Taiwan / 
   / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Orthoptera, Saltatoria
OR Oedaleus - Fieber 1853 (Saltatoria): [Key to species, China, P. 1016]. 
   Oedaleus kaohsiungensis (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Taiwan, P. 1013]. 
   Oedaleus nantouensis (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Taiwan, P. 1014]. 
   Oedaleus xiai (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Taiwan, P. 1013].

DT Article
TI THE SUBGENUS PULLUS OF SCYMNUS FROM CHINA (COLEOPTERA, COCCINELLIDAE).
   PART II: THE IMPEXUS GROUP.
AU Chen, Xiaosheng
   Huo, Lizhi
   Wang, Xingmin
   Canepari, Claudio
   Ren, Shunxiang (xiaoshchen@gmail.com) 
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 65
IS 3
PS 295-408
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 1
U2 12
AB The species of the impexus-group within the subgenus Scymnus (Pullus)
   Mulsant occurring in China are revised. Seventy-nine species are treated
   in this paper, among those 54 are described as new to science: Scymnus
   (Pullus) cuspidiger, S. (P.) sphenophyllus, S. (P.) yarangicus, S. (P.)
   pailongensis, S. (P.) multisetosus, S. (P.) dongjiuensis, S. (P.)
   yanlingicus, S. (P.) xujiabensis, S. (P.) mengshanus, S. (P.)
   liupanshanus, S. (P.) prolatus, S. (P.) spirellus, S. (P.) corallinus,
   S. (P.) pingbianensis, S. (P.) conoidalis, S. (P.) erythrinus, S. (P.)
   igneus, S. (P.) apophysatus, S. (P.) rufostriatus, S. (P.) lebuensis, S.
   (P.) seminiger, S. (P.) eminulus, S. (P.) quadratimaculatus, S. (P.)
   longicuspis, S. (P.) chelyospilicus, S. (P.) oculoformis, S. (P.)
   acerosus, S. (P.) dimidius, S. (P.) paraccamptus, S. (P.) paraexilis, S.
   (P.) yarlungzangbo, S. (P.) chayuensis, S. (P.) dipetalus, S. (P.)
   ensatus, S. (P.) leptophyllus, S. (P.) nielamuensis, S. (P.)
   ventricosus, S. (P.) rhinoides, S. (P.) maoershanensis, S. (P.)
   cibagouensis, S. (P.) ezhanus, S. (P.) jingdongensis, S. (P.) cyclotus,
   S. (P.) menglensis, S. (P.) rectangulus, S. (P.) bawanglingicus, S. (P.)
   rectiusculus, S. (P.) yaoquensis, S. (P.) barbatus, S. (P.) hanmianus,
   S. (P.) ciliosus, S. (P.) motuoensis, S. (P.) truncatus, S. (P.)
   linzhianus, spp. nov. Four species, S. (P.) martensi Canepari, 1997, S.
   (P.) janetscheki Bielawski, 1971, S. (P.) longisiphonatus Hoang, 1982
   and S. (P.) fruticis Canepari, 1997, are recorded from China for the
   first time. Keys, diagnoses, detailed descriptions, illustrations and
   distributions are provided for each species.

DT Article
TI CATALOGUE OF BIPHYLLIDAE (COLEOPTERA) OF THE WORLD.
AU Wegrzynowicz, Piotr (piotr.wegrzynowicz@gmail.com) 
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 65
IS 3
PS 409-471
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 2
U2 7
AB A catalogue of all known species of the family Biphyllidae is presented.
   All described extant and fossil species have been included, with
   synonyms, taxonomic notes, bionomy and distribution. Two new synonyms
   are proposed: Diphyllus lunatus var. inornatus Reitter, 1888 syn. nov.
   of Dermestes lunata Fabricius, 1787, and Thallestus typhaeoides var.
   obscuricollis Wollaston, 1865 syn. nov. of Thallestus typhaeoides
   Wollaston, 1862. Twenty three new combinations are proposed: Biphyllus
   alluaudi (Grouvelle, 1906), B. bolivari (Grouvelle, 1905), B.
   brunnescens (Reitter, 1877), B. canaliculatus (Grouvelle, 1906), B.
   concolor (Grouvelle, 1906), B. convexus (Reitter, 1878), B. dohrni
   (Reitter, 1877), B. escalerae (Grouvelle, 1905), B. histrio (Grouvelle,
   1906), B. liliputanus (Reitter, 1877), B. maculatus (Grouvelle, 1906),
   B. madagascariensis (Fairmaire, 1898), B. magnus (Grouvelle, 1906), B.
   minimus (Grouvelle, 1905), B. obscurus (Reitter, 1877), B. parvulus
   (Grouvelle, 1906), B. sicardi (Grouvelle, 1906), B. sordidus (Grouvelle,
   1906), B. subfasciatus (Reitter, 1878), B. undulatus (Grouvelle, 1906),
   B. v-notatus (Grouvelle, 1906), B. variegatus (Grouvelle, 1906), and B.
   wollastoni (Reitter, 1878). All above-mentioned species are being
   transferred from Diphyllus Berthold, 1827, which is an unjustified
   emendation of the name Biphyllus. Type species for three genera are
   designated: Anobocoelus championi Sharp, 1902 for Anobocoelus Sharp,
   1902; Gonicoelus unicornis Sharp, 1900: 605 for Gonicoelus Sharp, 1900:
   604; and Euderopus regularis Sharp, 1900 for Euderopus Sharp, 1900.
C1 Wegrzynowicz, Piotr; Univ Lodz, Inst Forest Sci, Ul Konstytucji 3 Maja
   65-67, Tomaszow Mazowiecki, PL-97200, Poland, Poland.
EM piotr.wegrzynowicz@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0003-4541; 1734-1833

   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Documentation; Publications
DE Biphyllidae [Catalogues / Distributional & taxonomic world catalogue /
   ].

DT Article
TI IDENTITY OF CHRYSOMELA JAVANICA THUNBERG, 1787 (COLEOPTERA:
   CHRYSOMELIDAE, TENEBRIONIDAE).
AU Bezdek, Jan
   Purchart, Lubos (bezdek@mendelu.cz) 
   Ando, Kiyoshi
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 65
IS 3
PS 473-478
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Based on a study of holotype, Chrysomela javanica Thunberg, 1787 was
   proved to be a representative of the genus Tetraphyllus Castelnau &
   Brulle, 1831 and is therefore transferred from Chrysomelidae to
   Tenebrionidae. New combination Tetraphyllus javanicus (Thunberg, 1787)
   (comb. nov.) is proposed. Tetraphyllus javanicus is redescribed and
   compared with its closest relative T. iridescens Ando, 1991. Colour
   photos of habitus of the type specimens of both taxa are presented. The
   checklist for all known species of the genus Tetraphyllus along with
   their known distribution is given.
C1 Purchart, Lubos; Mendel Univ, Dept Forest Ecol, Zemedelska 3, Brno,
   61300, Czech Republic, Czech Republic.
EM bezdek@mendelu.cz
RI Bezdek, Jan/J-3548-2018; Purchart, Lubos/B-2427-2014
OI Purchart, Lubos/0000-0001-9958-2300
SC Zoology
SN 0003-4541; 1734-1833
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Description; Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Documentation; Publications
DE Tetraphyllus [Checklists / Distributional checklist / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Chrysomeloidea,
   Chrysomelidae, Tenebrionoidea, Tenebrionidae
OR Phyllocharis javanica - (Thunberg 1787) (Chrysomelidae): [Referred to,
   Tetraphyllus, p. 474]. 
   Tetraphyllus (Tenebrionidae). 
   Tetraphyllus javanicus - (Thunberg 1787) (Tenebrionidae):
   [Redescription, P. 474; Comb nov, Transferred from Phyllocharis, p.
   474]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15202010435
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15202010436
DT Article
TI HANGAYA ENIGMATICA, A NEW GENUS AND SPECIES OF TENEBRIONIDAE FROM
   CENTRAL AUSTRALIA (COLEOPTERA).
AU Matthews, Eric G. (eric.matthews@samuseum.sa.gov.au) 
   Merkl, Otto
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 65
IS 3
PS 479-482
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Hangaya gen. nov. is proposed to receive H. enigmatica sp. nov. from the
   south of the Northern Territory, Australia. The new taxon is compared
   with other known groups and is found to agree with the characteristics
   of the subfamily Tenebrioninae, but not to agree completely with those
   of any known tribe in that subfamily.
C1 Matthews, Eric G.; S Australian Museum, N Terrace, Adelaide, SA, 5000,
   Australia, Australia.
EM eric.matthews@samuseum.sa.gov.au
SC Zoology
SN 0003-4541; 1734-1833
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Australasian region;
   Australasia; Australia
DE Hangaya enigmatica [Northern Territory /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Tenebrionoidea,
   Tenebrionidae
OR Hangaya (Tenebrionidae): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Tenebrioninae, Type
   species Hangaya enigmatica, p. 479]. 
   Hangaya enigmatica (Tenebrionidae): [Sp nov, Northern Territory, P.
   480].

DT Article
TI THE GENUS DRILUS (ELATERIDAE: AGRYPNINAE) IN LEVANT: A NEW SPECIES, NEW
   RECORDS AND UPDATED KEY TO THE MALES.
AU Petrzelkova, Ivana (ivana.petrzelkova01@upol.cz) 
   Kundrata, Robin
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 65
IS 3
PS 483-490
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Drilus rittneri sp. nov. is described from Israel and compared with its
   congeners from the Levant: Drilus adustus (Chevrolat, 1854), D.
   akbesianus (Fairmaire, 1895), D. bicolor Schaufuss, 1867, D. nemethi
   Kundrata, Kobieluszova & Bocak, 2014, D. rectus Schaufuss, 1867, and D.
   rufipes (Baudi di Selve, 1871). Data on the intraspecific variability
   and new distributional records for D. bicolor, D. rectus and D. rufipes
   are given. Drilus bicolor is recorded from Israel for the first time. An
   updated key to males of Drilus of the Levant is provided.
C1 Petrzelkova, Ivana; Palacky Univ, Fac Sci, 17 Listopadu 50, Olomouc,
   77146, Czech Republic, Czech Republic.
EM ivana.petrzelkova01@upol.cz
OI Kundrata, Robin/0000-0001-9397-1030

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia

DT Article
TI IMMATURE STAGES OF CHEWING LICE (INSECTA: PHTHIRAPTERA) FROM NEOTROPICAL
   ICTERIDAE (AVES: PASSERIFORMES), AND DESCRIPTIONS OF THREE NEW SPECIES.
AU Valim, Michel P. (mpvalim@hotmail.com) 
   Cicchino, Armando C.
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 65
IS 3
PS 491-521
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A morphological study of six little known or undescribed species of
   chewing lice parasitic on cowbirds (Icteridae) is given, based on a
   holistic approach which includes descriptions of the pre-imaginal
   stages. Both sexes, the last two nymphal stages and eggs of the new
   species Myrsidea amblyramphidis (Amblycera: Menoponidae) are described
   and illustrated (type host: Amblyramphus holosericeus (Scopoli)). Also,
   the male with all pre-imaginal stages (including hatching organ of
   nymph, egg and the three nymphal stages) of Menacanthus leistidis
   Cicchino, 1984 from Leistes superciliaris (Bonaparte) is described for
   the first time and the female is redescribed; a discussion of the
   morphological affinities with its closest species, M. sturnellae Price,
   1977 is included. Among the Ischnocera (Philopteridae s.l.), both sexes
   and the last pre-imaginal stages of two incompletely known species of
   Brueelia Keler, 1936, B. mirabile Carriker, 1963 from Molothrus o.
   oryzivorus (Gmelin), and B. oxypyga (Giebel, 1874) from A. holosericeus
   are described. Furthermore, two new species of Brueelia, B. chopi from
   Gnorimopsar chopi (Vieillot), and B. paradoxa from Leistes superciliaris
   are described from both sexes and their last two pre-imaginal stages,
   and eggs.
C1 Valim, Michel P.; Univ Sao Paulo, Museum Zool, Sao Paulo, Brazil,
   Brazil.
EM mpvalim@hotmail.com

DT Article
TI Remarks on synonyms of European Larinioides species (Arachnida: Araneae:
   Araneidae).
AU Breitling, Rainer (rainer.breitling@manchester.ac.uk) 
   Bauer, Tobias
SO Arachnology
VL 16
IS 9
PS 305-310
PD Fal 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The five European species of the genus Larinioides are among the most
   conspicuous spiders of the area, and some of them can be the dominant
   orb weavers of their habitat. Three of the species were described by
   Clerck (1757), yet their nomenclatural history since then has been
   marred by considerable confusion. Only in the last 40 years has the
   nomenclature in the genus gradually stabilized. Recently, however, it
   has been suggested to rename two of the species (Larinioides
   sclopetarius and L. suspicax) yet again. This note intends to show that
   these recent name changes are not supported by the available evidence,
   and that the established names L. sclopetarius and L. suspicax continue
   to be valid.
C1 Breitling, Rainer; Univ Manchester, Fac Life Sci, Manchester, Lancs, M1
   7DN, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM rainer.breitling@manchester.ac.uk
OI Breitling, Rainer/0000-0001-7173-0922
SC Zoology
SN 2050-9928
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Taxonomy
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Araneae
OR Larinioides cornutus - (Clerck 1757) (Araneae): [Removal from synonymy,
   Larinioides sclopetarius (Clerck 1757), p. 307]. 
   Larinioides patagiatus - (Clerck 1757) (Araneae): [Syn nov, Aranea
   folium Schrank 1803, p. 308; Syn nov, Larinioides dumetorum (Fourcroy
   1785), p. 308; Syn nov, Larinioides subflavus (Martini & Goeze 1778), p.
   308]. 
   Larinioides sclopetarius - (Clerck 1757) (Araneae): [Removal from
   synonymy, With Larinioides cornutus (Clerck 1757), p. 307]. 
   Larinioides suspicax - (O. Pickard-Cambridge 1876) (Araneae): [Status,
   P. 307]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15202013681
DA 2020-09-17

TI New species of spiders from Sardinia (Araneae), with ecological notes on
   Lipocrea epeiroides (O. Pickard-Cambridge, 1872) (Araneae: Araneidae).
AU Bosmans, Robert (rop_bosmans@telenet.be) 
   Colombo, Marco
SO Arachnology
VL 16
IS 9
PS 319-332
PD Fal 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Centromerus isaiai Bosmans n. sp. is described on both sexes on
   specimens collected in Sardinia and Corsica. Palliduphantes paoloi
   Wunderlich, 1995 is a junior synonym of P angustiformis (Simon, 1884).
   Palliduphantes prodigialis (Simon, 1884) is removed from the synonymy of
   P. angustiformis Simon, 1884 and placed in the synonymy of P. longisetus
   Simon, 1884. Lipocrea epeiroides (O. Pickard-Cambridge, 1872) and
   Tapinopa disjugata Simon, 1884 are new species for Italy; first detailed
   ecological notes are given for the former one. Fourteen species are
   added to the fauna of Sardinia.

   Belgium, Belgium.
EM rop_bosmans@telenet.be

DT Article
TI Conductor-less and vertically niched: new species of the genus
   Pseudopoda (Araneae: Sparassidae: Heteropodinae) from Myanmar.
AU Jaeger, Peter (peter.jaeger@senckenberg.de) 
SO Arachnology
VL 16
IS 9
PS 333-350
PD Fal 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Material of the genus Pseudopoda Jager, 2000 from Myanmar is revised.
   Six new species are described: Pseudopoda tji sp. nov., P pingu sp.
   nov., P bangaga sp. nov., P wamwo sp. nov., P martinschuberti sp. nov.
   (all: male, female; Chin State) and P huberi sp. nov. (male; Mandalay
   Region). All species were recorded from elevations above 600 m. All five
   species from Nat Ma Taung are vertically niched in zones of up to 500 m
   elevation difference. Moreover, males of all these species lack the
   conductor of the male palp, four of them exhibit a special glandular
   appendage in the female internal duct system, as well as a unique
   reduction of tibial spines in both sexes. A special brush of setae on
   the distal cymbium is identified as a possible surrogate structure
   acting as a secondary conductor.
C1 Jaeger, Peter; Senckenberg Res Inst, Arachnol, Senckenberganlage 25,
   Frankfurt, D-60325, Germany, Germany.
EM peter.jaeger@senckenberg.de
SC Zoology
SN 2050-9928
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Pseudopoda bangaga; Pseudopoda huberi; Pseudopoda martinschuberti;
   Pseudopoda pingu; Pseudopoda tji; Pseudopoda wamwo [Myanmar /  / New
   species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Araneae
OR Pseudopoda bangaga (Araneae): [Sp nov, Myanmar, P. 338]. 
   Pseudopoda huberi (Araneae): [Sp nov, Myanmar, P. 346]. 
   Pseudopoda martinschuberti (Araneae): [Sp nov, Myanmar, P. 343]. 
   Pseudopoda pingu (Araneae): [Sp nov, Myanmar, P. 336]. 
   Pseudopoda tji (Araneae): [Sp nov, Myanmar, P. 333]. 
   Pseudopoda wamwo (Araneae): [Sp nov, Myanmar, P. 341].

TI A new species of Amycus C. L. Koch, 1846 (Salticidae: Amycoida:
   Amycinae) from Colombia, with a new record of A. spectabilis C. L. Koch,
   1846.

   department of Meta, Colombia: the first official record of the genus
   from the country. A. spectabilis C. L. Koch, 1846 is recorded for the
   first time from Colombia, from the eastern and Amazonian departments of
   Meta and Guaviare, respectively.

DT Article
TI New and interesting Carabus Linnaeus, 1758 (Coleoptera Carabidae) from
   Korean Peninsula.
AU Rapuzzi, Ivan (info@ronchidicialla.it) 
SO Biodiversity Journal
VL 6
IS 3
PS 723-748
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB An extensive contribution to the genus Carabus Linnaeus, 1758
   (Coleoptera Carabidae) from Korean Peninsula is provided. One new
   species and 14 new subspecies are described and figured: Carabus
   (Acoptolabrus) planicranion n. sp., C. (Carabus) szeli obong n. ssp., C.
   (Carabus) angustus dopyeong n. ssp., C. (Carabus) sternbergi gimhwa n.
   ssp., C. (Carabus) sternbergi goheungicus n. ssp., C. (Carabus)
   sternbergi jindoensis n. ssp., C. (Carabus) sternbergi deogyusan n.
   ssp., C. (Carabus) cartereti peacedam n. ssp., C. (Carabus) fraterculus
   yongwangicus n. ssp., C. (Acoptolabrus) constricticollis microcolasellus
   n. ssp., C. (Acoptolabrus) leechi viniciosalamii n. ssp., C.
   (Acoptolabrus) leechi drouini n. ssp., C. (Coptolabrus) jankowskii
   byeoksanensis n. ssp., C. (Coptolabrus) smaragdinus buangun n. ssp., C.
   (Coptolabrus) smaragdinus euaureus n. ssp. A new natural hybrid is
   described and figured: C. (Leptocarabus) seishinensis seishinensis
   Lapouge, 1931 x C. (Leptocarabus) semiopacus Reitter, 1895. Two
   taxonomic changes are proposed: C. (Isiocarabus) kirinicus Csiki, 1927
   bona species and C. (Isiocarabus) saishutoicus Csiki, 1927 bona species
   and additional information are provided for several little known taxa.

DT Article
TI Kabatekiipsebium yemenensis new genus and new species from Arabic
   Peninsula (Coleoptera Cerambycidae).
AU Rapuzzi, Pierpaolo (info@ronchidicialla.it) 
SO Biodiversity Journal
VL 6
IS 3
PS 753-756
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Kabatekiipsebium yemenensis new genus and new species is described from
   yemen and oman. the new genus belongs to psebiini Lacordaire, 1869 tribe
   and it is close to Pectinopsebium-Adlbauer, 2012 and Bostrychopsebium
   Quentin et Villiers, 1971 but it is strictly related to Pectinopsebium
   by the shape of the antennae in both sexes. the new genus is easy to
   distinguish from all other genera of psebiini by its particular shape of
   antennae, the length of the elytra and legs, and for the very small size
   of its body.
C1 Rapuzzi, Pierpaolo; Via Cialla 48, Udine, I-33040, Italy, Italy.
EM info@ronchidicialla.it
SC Zoology
SN 2039-0394; 2039-0408
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia

   described, Phylloxiphia colasi n. sp. and P. domi n. sp., respectively
   closely allied to P. vicina (Rothschild & Jordan, 1904) and to P. oweni

DT Article
TI New genera and species of the tribe Acratini (Coleoptera, Brentidae).
FT Nouveaux genres et especes de la tribu des Acratini (Coleoptera,
   Brentidae).
AU Mantilleri, Antoine (amantill@mnhn.fr) 
SO Bulletin de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 120
IS 3
PS 267-296
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB On the basis of the phylogenetic analysis of external and internal
   morphological characters of 29 Acratini (with special attention given to
   sclerites of the internal sac of aedeagus), three new genera are
   described in this neotropical tribe: Rugosacratus n. gen. (type species
   Acratus chontalensis Sharp, 1895), Teramoceroides n. gen. (type species
   Belorhynchus gracilis Boheman, 1833), and Parateramocerus n. gen. (type
   species Proteramocerus goianus Soares & Dias, 1971). The creation of
   those new generic divisions leads to the following new combinations:
   Rugosacratus punctirostris (Boheman, 1840), n. comb., R. chontalensis
   (Sharp, 1895), n. comb., Teramoceroides gracilis (Boheman, 1833), n.
   comb., T. belti (Sharp, 1895), n. comb., T. mamillatus (Meyer, 1959), n.
   comb., and Parateramocerus goianus (Soares & Dias, 1971), n. comb.,
   Three new species are described: Rugosacratus eximius n. sp. from French
   Guiana, Brazil, Ecuador and Peru, Teramocerus asklerosis n. sp. from
   French Guiana and Brazil, and T. rileyi n. sp. from Panama. The
   distribution of the species is updated and discussed. Teramoceroides
   belti is newly recorded from Colombia and Panama; T. mamillatus is newly
   recorded from French Guiana; Rugosacratus punctirostris is new for
   Colombia, French Guiana and Venezuela; Teramocerus pulcher (Soares &
   Dias, 1971) is newly recorded from French Guiana.
C1 Mantilleri, Antoine; Museum Natl Hist Nat, Entomol, CP 50,57 Rue Cuvier,
   Paris, F-75213, France, France.
EM amantill@mnhn.fr
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Evolutionary Biology

   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; General morphology; Evolution; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; Central America; South America
DE Acratini [Neotropical region /  / Biology; distribution; systematics]. 
   Brentidae [General morphology /  / new record; systematics] [Phylogeny /
   Phylogenetic relationships / ] [Neotropical region /  / biology;
   distribution]. 
   Proteramocerus eximius [Brazil /  / New species] [Colombia /  / ]
   [Ecuador /  / ] [French Guiana /  / ] [Peru /  / ].

   Rugosacratus (Brentidae): [Gen nov, Of tribe Acratini, Type species
   Acratus chontalensis Sharp 1895, p. 268].

   Transferred from Proteramocerus, p. 269]. 
   Rugosacratus punctirostris (Brentidae): [New record]. 
   Teramoceroides (Brentidae): [Gen nov, Of tribe Acratini, Type species
   Belorhynchus gracilis Boheman 1833, p. 279].

DT Article
TI The mealybug Trionymus angustifrons Hall transferred to Dysmicoccus
   Ferris with new synonymy (Hemiptera, Sternorrhyncha, Coccomorpha,
   Pseudococcidae).
AU Matile-Ferrero, Daniele (dmatile@mnhn.fr) 
   Williams, Douglas J.
   Kaydan, M. Bora
SO Bulletin de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 120
IS 3
PS 309-312
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The mealybug Trionymus angustifrons Hall, 1926, is transferred to the
   genus Dysmicoccus Ferris, 1950, as a new combination, Dysmicoccus
   angustifrons (Hall, 1926), n. comb. The original names Pseudococcus
   multivorus Kiritchenko, 1936, and P. lanatus Balachowsky, 1932, are
   treated as new junior synonyms of Dysmicoccus angustifrons (Hall, 1926),
   a species belonging to a group with reduced numbers of cerarii and with
   two sizes of oral collar tubular ducts on the dorsum and venter.
   Lectotypes are designated for Trionymus angustifrons and Pseudococcus
   lanatus. Spain and mainland Greece are new locality records for the
   species.
C1 Matile-Ferrero, Daniele; Museum Natl Hist Nat, CNRS, CP 50,57 Rue
   Cuvier, Paris, F-75231, France, France.
EM dmatile@mnhn.fr
SC Zoology
SN 0037-928X

   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia;
   Europe
DE Dysmicoccus angustifrons [Greece /  / New record] [Spain /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Homoptera, Sternorrhyncha,
   Coccoidea

   Transferred from Trionymus, p. 310; Syn nov, Pseudococcus lanatus
   Balachowsky 1932, p. 310; Syn nov, Pseudococcus multivorus Kiritchenko
   1936, p. 310; New record]. 
   Pseudococcus lanatus - Balachowsky 1932 (Coccoidea): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 310].

DT Article
TI Revision of the genus Heliosthraema Reitter, 1890, endemic to Morocco
   (Coleoptera, Tenebrionidae, Alleculinae).
FT Revision du genre Heliosthraema Reitter, 1890, endemique du Maroc
   (Coleoptera, Tenebrionidae, Alleculinae).
AU Bouyon, Herve (herve.bouyon@wanadoo.fr) 
SO Bulletin de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 120
IS 3
PS 313-322
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Heliosthraema is revised. A new species, Heliosthraema
   prudhommei n. sp., is described and a new synonymy is proposed:
   Heliotaurus griseolineatus var. alterneseriatus Escalera, 1911, n. syn.
   for Omophlus (Heliosthraema) griseolineatus Reitter, 1890. A new
   locality data is given for H. reymondi Pic, 1953, and the male of this
   species is described. An identification key to species of the genus
   Heliosthraema is provided and a lectotype is designated for H.
   griseolineatum (Reitter, 1890). The geographical distribution of the
   different species is precised.

TI Revision of the genus Degallierister Gomy, 2001 (Coleoptera, Histeridae,

AB New distributional and morphological data and illustrations are given
   for the nine species already known in the neotropical genus
   Degallierister Gomy, 2001: D. barberoi Gomy, 2001, D. diquis Gomy, 2013,
   D. hamatus (Lewis, 1888), D. hielkemai Gomy, 2013, D. penatii Gamy,
   2001, D. peruvianus (Mazur, 1988), D. pseudohamatus (Kanaar, 1981), D.
   pusillus (Wenzel, 1944) and D. surinamensis Gomy, 2013. Ten new species
   are described: D. antoinei n. sp., D. bihamatus n. sp., D. greglamarrei
   n. sp., D. kanaari n. sp., D. lewisi n. sp., D. lissosternum n. sp., D.
   parenthesis n. sp., D. rogeri n. sp., D. striatus n. sp. and D. yvesi n.
   sp. D. peruvianus is newly recorded from Bolivia. D. barberoi is newly
   recorded from Costa Rica and Peru. D. penatii is newly recorded from
   Brazil, French Guiana, Guyana and Panama. D. diquis is newly recorded
   from Brazil and Panama. D. hielkemai is newly recorded from Brazil,
   Guyana and Peru. D. surinamensis is newly recorded from Brazil, French
   Guiana, Guyana and Peru. An identification key is presented for all
   known species.

   Spain (Coleoptera, Carabidae, Trechinae).

   Espana (Coleoptera, Carabidae, Trechinae).
AU Fresneda, Javier (ffresned@gmail.com) 
   Valenzuela, Enrique
   Faille, Arnaud
SO Bulletin de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 120
IS 3
PS 403-409
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Trechus bourdeaui n. sp. is described from the Cantabrian Mountains in
   Spain: Sierra del Aramo, Asturias. This species was collected in caves,
   subterranean environment. Morphological evidences demonstrate that the
   new species belongs to the Trechus saxicola clade (sensu Faille et al.,
   2013). We discuss the taxonomy of the new species and provide
   illustrations of structures showing differences between T. bourdeaui n.
   sp. and T. saxicola Putzeys, 1870.

DT Article
TI A new giant leaf insect species of the genus Phyllium from Thailand
   (Phasmatodea, Phylliidae).
AU Delfosse, Emmanuel (delfosse@mnhn.fr) 
SO Bulletin de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 120
IS 3
PS 411-415
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new species of leaf insect is described from Thailand, Phyllium
   (Pukhriphyllium) maethoraniae n. sp., very close to P (Pulchriphyllium)
   sinense Liu, 1990, but differs by various distinct characters such as
   the armature of the mesonotum, shape of the anterior legs, abdomen and
   abdominal apex. Like P sinense, P maethoraniae n. sp. is only known from
   the female. A table is given to distinguish between the two species.
C1 Delfosse, Emmanuel; Museum Natl Hist Nat, Entomol, CP 50,57 Rue Cuvier,
   Paris, F-75231, France, France.
EM delfosse@mnhn.fr
SC Zoology

DT Article
TI Shell morphology and habitat of Fulvia sp., a candidate for ancestral
   species of extant F. mutica (Bivalvia: Cardiidae) from the Pliocene
   Ananai Formation.
AU Yamaoka, Yuta (b14d6a02@s.kochi-u.ac.jp) 
   Otsuka, Yusuke
   Kondo, Yasuo
SO Fossils (Tokyo)
VL 98
PS 5-15
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA Japanese
U1 0
U2 0
AB Fulvia sp., a candidate species for the direct ancestor of Fulvia mutica
   (Cardiidae) that usually lives in muddy substrates of sheltered bays
   around Japan, was found from the Pliocene Ananai Formation in Kochi.
   Fulvia sp. has been misleadingly assigned to the extant species F.
   mutica, because both morphotypes are very similar in shell form.
   However, Fulvia sp. has a characteristic radial groove between shell
   surface inflations corresponding to inhalant and exhalent siphons, while
   it is absent in recent F. mutica. The average shell size of Fulvia sp.
   is about one third of that of F. mutica. In addition, observation of the
   daily growth lines in cross section indicates that the average life span
   of Fulvia sp. is much shorter than F. mutica. Fulvia sp. occurs mostly
   from sandy storm deposits formed in lower shoreface and inner shelf,
   while extant F. mutica usually lives in muddy substrates in embayed
   environments. Moreover, all the fossil records of F. mutica are younger
   than 2.8-2.0 Ma, whereas the appearance datum of Fulvia sp. is ascended
   to 3.1 Ma. F. mutica might have been evolved from Fulvia sp. and adapted
   to cooler climate during Late Pliocene/Early Pleistocene period
   acquiring larger shell-size and a new habitat in muddy sheltered bay.
C1 Yamaoka, Yuta; Kochi Univ, Fac Sci, Akebono Cho 2-5-1, Kochi, 7808520,
   Japan, Japan.
EM b14d6a02@s.kochi-u.ac.jp
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Developmental Biology; Evolutionary
   Biology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Paleontology
SN 0022-9202
BD Skeletal and supporting structures; Shell; Life cycle and development;
   Development; Evolution; Ecology; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene
DE Fulvia [Shell morphology /  / ] [Growth / Shell growth / ] [Speciation /
   / ] [Ecology / Habitat / ] [Japan / Shikoku, Kochi / ] [Pliocene /  / ].
   
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Bivalvia, Heterodonta, Veneroida, Cardioidea
OR Fulvia (Cardioidea): [Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15202012388
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR15202009933
PM 25999590
DT Article
TI Pseudomonas coleopterorum sp nov., a cellulase-producing bacterium
   isolated from the bark beetle Hylesinus fraxini.
AU Menendez, Esther
   Ramirez-Bahena, Martha H.
   Fabryova, Anna
   Igual, Jose M.
   Benada, Oldrich
   Mateos, Pedro F.
   Peix, Alvaro
   Kolarik, Miroslav
   Garcia-Fraile, Paula (garcia@biomed.cas.cz) 
SO International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology
VL 65
IS 9
PS 2852-2858
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 29
AB We isolated a strain coded Esc2AmT during a study focused on the
   microbial diversity of adult specimens of the bark beetle Hylesinus
   fraxini. Its 16S rRNA gene sequence had 99.4 % similarity with respect
   to its closest relative, Pseudomonas rhizosphaerae IH5T. The analysis of
   partial sequences of the housekeeping genes rpoB, rpoD and gyrB
   confirmed that strain Esc2AmT formed a cluster with P. rhizosphaerae
   IH5T clearly separated from the remaining species of the genus
   Pseudomonas. Strain Esc2AmT had polar flagella and could grow at
   temperatures from 4 [degree]C to 30 [degree]C. The respiratory quinone
   was 09 and the main fatty acids were C16 : 0, C18 : 1[omega]7c and/or
   C18 : 1[omega]6c in summed feature 8 and C16 : 1[omega]7c and/or C18 :
   1[omega]6c in summed feature 3. DNA DNA hybridization results showed 51
   % relatedness with respect to P. rhizosphaerae IH5T. Oxidase, catalase
   and urease-positive, the arginine dihydrolase system was present but
   nitrate reduction and [beta]-galactosidase production were negative.
   Aesculin hydrolysis was positive. Based on the results from the
   genotypic, phenotypic and chemotaxonomic analyses, we propose the
   classification of strain Esc2AmT as representing a novel species of the
   genus Pseudomonas, for which we propose the name Pseudomonas
   coleopterorum sp. nov. The type strain is Esc2AmT (=LMG 28558T=CECT
   8695T).
C1 Garcia-Fraile, Paula; Acad Sci Czech Republ, Inst Microbiol, Prague,
   Czech Republic, Czech Republic.
EM garcia@biomed.cas.cz

   Ramirez-Bahena, Martha Helena/B-8564-2017; Benada, Oldrich/H-2437-2014;
   Igual, Jose M/B-6993-2015; Fraile, Paula Garcia/N-8193-2014; Menendez,
   Esther/S-3387-2016; Peix, Alvaro/A-7196-2010
OI Kolarik, Miroslav/0000-0003-4016-0335; Mateos,
   Pedro/0000-0003-1628-598X; Ramirez-Bahena, Martha

PM 25999593
DT Article
TI Pichia dushanensis sp nov and Hyphopichia paragotoi sp nov., two sexual
   yeast species associated with insects and rotten wood.
AU Ren, Yong-Cheng
   Liu, Si-Tong
   Li, Ying
   Hui, Feng-Li (fenglihui@yeah.net) 
SO International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology
VL 65
IS 9
PS 2875-2881
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Seven yeast strains were isolated from the gut of insect larvae and
   decayed wood, which were collected from three localities near Nanyang,
   Henan Province, China. These strains were identified as two novel
   species through comparison of sequences in the D1/D2 domains of the
   large subunit (LSU) rRNA gene and other taxonomic characteristics.
   Pichia dushanensis sp. nov. was closely related to species in the Pichia
   clade and produced one to four spheroid ascospores in a deliquescent
   ascus. The D1/D2 sequence of P. dushanensis sp. nov. differed from its
   closest relative, lssatchenkia (Pichia) sp. NRRL Y-12824, by 3.6 %
   sequence divergence (16 substitutions and 4 gaps). The species also
   differed from its four closest known species, Candida rugopelliculosa,
   Pichia occidentalis, Pichia exigua and Candida phayaonensis, by 4.1-4.4
   % sequence divergence (22-24 substitutions and 0-2 gaps) in the D1/D2
   sequences. Hyphopichia paragotoi sp. nov. belonged to the Hyphopichia
   clade, and its nearest phylogenetic neighbours were Candida gotoi,
   Candida pseudorhagii, Candida rhagii and Hyphopichia heimii with
   3.2-4.2% sequence divergence (16-21substitutions and 1 gap) in the D1/D2
   sequences. In comparison with previously established species, H.
   paragotoi sp. nov. formed one hat-shaped ascospore in a persistent
   ascus. The type strain of P. dushanensis sp. nov. is NYNU 14658T (=CICC
   33049T=CBS 13912T), and the type strain of H. paragotoi sp. nov. is NYNU
   14666T (=CICC 33048T=CBS 13913T).
C1 Hui, Feng-Li; Nanyang Normal Univ, Sch Life Sci & Technol, Nanyang,
   473061, China, China.
EM fenglihui@yeah.net
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 1466-5026
BD Associations; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Coleoptera [Associations / Hyphopichia paragotoi (fungus) / New species;
   larva] [ / Pichia dushanensis (fungus) / ] [Henan / Nanyang / Fungal
   associates]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta
OR Coleoptera (Insecta). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15202009934
OA Bronze

DT Article
TI Winogradskyella crassostreae sp nov., isolated from an oyster
   (Crassostrea gigas).
AU Park, Sooyeon
   Park, Ji-Min
   Won, Sung-Min
   Yoon, Jung-Hoon (jhyoon69@skku.edu) 
SO International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology
VL 65
IS 9
PS 2890-2895
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB A Gram-stain-negative, non-flagellated, non-gliding, aerobic and
   rod-shaped bacterium, designated TYO-19T, was isolated from an oyster
   collected from the South Sea in South Korea, and was subjected to a
   taxonomic study using a polyphasic approach. Strain TYO-19T grew
   optimally at 30 [degree]C, at pH 7.0-8.0 and in the presence of 1.0-2.0
   % (w/v) NaCl. Phylogenetic trees based on 16S rRNA gene sequences showed
   that strain TYO-19T belonged to the genus Winogradskyella, clustering
   coherently with the type strain of Winogradskyella epiphytica. Strain
   TYO-19T exhibited a 16S rRNA gene sequence similarity value of 99.7 % to
   W. epiphytica KMM 3906T and 94.2-96.9 % to the type strains of other
   species of the genus Winogradskyella. Strain TY0-19T contained MK-6 as
   the predominant menaquinone and iso-C15:1 G, iso-C17:0 3-OH, iso-C15:0
   and anteiso-C15:0 as the major fatty acids. The major polar lipids
   detected in strain TY0-19T were phosphatidylethanolamine and one
   unidentified lipid. The DNA G+C content was 39.0 mol% and the mean DNA
   DNA relatedness value with the type strain of W. epiphytica was 59[plus
   or minus]4.3 %. Differential phenotypic properties, together with
   phylogenetic and genetic distinctiveness, revealed that strain TYO-19T
   is separated from recognized species of the genus Winogradskyella. On
   the basis of the data presented, strain TYO-19T is considered to
   represent a novel species of the genus Winogradskyella, for which the
   name Winogradskyella crassostreae sp. nov. is proposed. The type strain
   is TY0-19T (=KCTC 42462T=NBRC 110924T).
C1 Yoon, Jung-Hoon; Sungkyunkwan Univ, Dept Food Sci & Biotechnol, Suwon,
   South Korea, South Korea.
EM jhyoon69@skku.edu
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 1466-5026
BD Associations; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Crassostrea gigas [Associations / Winogradskyella crassostreae
   (bacterium) / New species] [North Pacific / South Korea, Tongyeong,
   South Sea / Bacterial associates]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Bivalvia, Pteriomorphia, Ostreoida, Ostreoidea
OR Crassostrea gigas (Ostreoidea).

DT Article
TI Bizionia fulviae sp nov., isolated from the gut of an egg cockle, Fulvia
   mutica.
AU Kim, Hyun Sik
   Hyun, Dong-Wook
   Kim, Pil Soo
   Lee, June-Young
   Shin, Na-Ri
   Yun, Ji-Hyun
   Whon, Tae Woong
   Kim, Min-Soo
   Jung, Mi-Ja
   Bae, Jin-Woo (baejw@khu.ac.kr) 
SO International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology
VL 65
IS 9
PS 3066-3072
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 1
U2 4
AB A novel Gram-staining-negative, non-spore-forming, non-flagellated,
   non-motile, aerobic, saffron-coloured, rod-shaped bacterium that did not
   produce flexirubin-type pigments was designated strain EM7T and was
   distinct from other members of the genus Bizionia by produce
   carotenoid-type pigments and being able to grow independently of NaCl.
   Strain EM7T was isolated from the intestinal tract of an egg cockle, Ful
   via mutica, which had been collected from the West Sea in Korea.
   Phylogenetic analysis based on the 16S rRNA gene sequence showed that
   strain EM7T belonged to the genus Bizionia, and showed sequence
   similarity to Bizionia paragorgiae KMM 6029T (97.9 %) and Bizionia
   saleffrena HFDT (97.73 %). Growth occurred on marine agar 2216 at 0-25
   [degree]C (optimum, 20 [degree]C) and at pH 6-9 (optimum, pH 7). Growth
   occurred in the presence of 0-10 % (w/v) NaCl (optimum, 2 %, w/v, NaCl).
   The major cellular fatty acids were anteiso-C15 :0, iso-C15 :0, iso-C15
   :1 G, summed feature 3 (C16:1 [omega]7c and/or C16: 1[omega]6c, iSO-C17
   : 0 3-OH and iso-C16 :0 3-OH. The major respiratory quinone was
   menaquinone MK-6. The polar lipids of strain EM7T comprised
   phosphatidylethanolamine, three unidentified aminolipids, an
   unidentified aminophospholipid and two unidentified lipids. The genomic
   DNA G + C content was 34.8 mol%. Bizionia paragorgiae KMM 6029T and
   Bizionia saleffrena HFDT to Bizionia paragorgiae KCTC 12304T and
   Bizionia saleffrena CIP 108534T, respectively. Thus, it is proposed that
   the isolate represents a novel species, Bizionia fulviae sp. nov., with
   strain EM7T (=KACC 18255T=JCM 30417T) as the type strain.
C1 Bae, Jin-Woo; Kyung Hee Univ, Dept Life & Nanopharmaceut Sci, Seoul,
   130701, South Korea, South Korea.
EM baejw@khu.ac.kr

   species] [North Pacific / South Korea, West Sea / Bacterial associates].

DT Article
TI Revision of the Hydaticus (Prodaticus) sexguttatus species group, and
   resembling species from the Palearctic, Oriental, Australian and Pacific
   Regions (Coleoptera: Dytiscidae).
AU Wewalka, G. (g.wewalka@gmx.at) 
SO Koleopterologische Rundschau
VL 85
PS 7-55
PD Sep 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Palearctic, Oriental, Australian and Pacific species of the
   Hydaticus (Prodaticus) sexguttatus species group (Coleoptera,
   Dytiscidae) are revised. Fourteen species including five new ones (H.
   balkei sp.n., H. hajeki sp.n., H. hendrichi sp.n., H. marlenae sp.n. and
   H. stastnyi sp.n.) are described. Five species of the H. fabricii group
   including one new species and one new subspecies (H. agaboides SHARP,
   1882, H. ephippiiger REGIMBART, 1899, H. larsoni sp.n., H. pulcher
   CLARK, 1863, H. sellatus sabahensis ssp.n. and H. sellatus sellatus
   REGIMBART, 1883) are also treated herein, because their elytral marks or
   their male genitalia are similar to those of some species of the H.
   sexguttatus group. Lectotypes are designated for H. bengalensis
   REGIMBART, 1899, H ephippiiger REGIMBART, 1899, H. fractifer WALKER,
   1858, H laetabilis REGIMBART, 1899, H. macularis REGIMBART, 1899, H.
   nigritulus REGIMBART, 1899, H reductus REGIMBART, 1899, H
   rhantaticoides., REGIMBART, 1892, H schultzei ZIMMERMANN, 1924, H
   sellatus REGIMBART, 1883, and H. sexguttatus REGIMBART, 1899. New
   synonymies: H. firms WATTS, 1978 (= H. ephippiiger REGIMBART, 1899), H
   reductus REGIMBART, 1899 (= H platteeuwi SEVERIN, 1890), H schulizei
   ZIMMERMANN, 1924 (= H macularis REGIMBART, 1899), H wattsi DAUSSIN, 1980
   (= H. rhantaticoides REGIMBART, 1892). A key to the species of the H.
   sexguttatus group of the Palearctic, Oriental, Australian and Pacific
   Regions and resembling species of the H. fabricii group is provided. The
   known distribution of each species is outlined. Important diagnostic
   characters are illustrated.

   designated, P. 18; Syn nov, Hydaticus schultzei Zimmermann 1924, p. 18;
   New record].

   P. 14].

   record].
